newsitem.title: CANADA: Toronto stocks close softer, pulled down by golds.
newsitem.headline: Toronto stocks close softer, pulled down by golds.

text.p: Toronto stocks ended easier on Wednesday, dragged lower by a sell-off in financial service issues, while the value of trading was the third-highest ever.
The Toronto Stock Exchange key 300 Composite Index fell 7.96 points to close at 5799.01 points, before setting a new intra-day high of 5816.40 points.
Trading volume was 133.2 million shares worth C$2.29 billion. The TSE's highest trading value was C$2.53 billion (US$1.9 billion), set in April 1986.
RBC Dominion Securities analyst Dunnery Best noted that bank stocks were retreating from their recent rally.
"Weaker bond markets are fueling the shift away from the interest sensitives into the more glorious investing terrain of golds and the cyclicals," Best said in a market report.

Ron Meisels, president of P and C Holdings Ltd, added that a pause was warranted after the TSE 300 Index added about 200 points since November 5. "It would be quite normal and understandable for it to have a correction after such a robust move," Meisels said.
Toronto's 14 sub-indices were evenly split between rising and falling groups. Pipelines lost the most ground, followed by banks, utilities, and conglomerates.
Golds, base metals and communications led the gaining side.
Advancing issues edged out declining ones 492 to 473 while 315 traded flat.
* Nickel giant Inco Ltd rose 1.80 to 45.95 in heavy trading while gold firm Euro-Nevada Mining Corp Ltd topped net gainers, adding 2.55 to reach 42.80.
